author: greystroke
content:
The ACD governance process seems to be broken in respect to the process of eip inclusion & removal with the 11 SFI'd EOF eips being DFI'd in a single call. Contrary to <@552133098075193354> conjecture that there isn't a dominant EF position on EOF https://discord.com/channels/595666850260713488/745077610685661265/1368760092777775236 I think it appears to most observers of the ACD calls that the EF has taken a (belatedly) firm position against EOF inclusion based on the following:
1. The goal posts have seemingly moved from a Supermajority of client teams and core devs required for rough consensus on the EOF eips to Unanimity. This has not been the case for any other eips I can recall and was a decision made by <@552133098075193354> who represents the EF when he chairs the ACD calls. 
2. <@489256758989029405> stated he has full faith in how <@552133098075193354> handled the decision re: DFIing the 11 SFI'd EOF eips
3. <@273808422753796097> subtly endorsed this position by both not criticizing it and not explicitly supporting EOF. In addition, he stated his belief that RISC-V is the likely endgame for the Ethereum VM, implying EOF is not a priority.

author: pipermerriam
content: Maybe one way to look at what just happened is that ACD has not ever truly formalized it's decision making process.  No formal membership.  No formal voting.  The EOF decision may be one of our first really contentious decisions where this lack of formality leaves the decision feeling like it violated the process.  Supermajority vs Unanimity vs whatever our interpretations of the process have been.  I believe there's been some loose consensus in the past that avoiding formalization of process is a mechanism to avoid capture... and this is potentially a negative outcome of lack of formalization of our process.

author: wjmelements
content: Several chains are doing much more than 3m gas/sec. The main risk of going full throttle is sync time imo, as it takes longer to catch up or start from zero. It‚Äôs true that some validators want to go full throttle and others want to burn more ether but the dictator in the current system is the median voter. I suspect they haven‚Äôt thought about it very much. They might be swayed by analysis, or (more likely) default settings.

author: tersec
content:
One difference, structurally, with EOF is that all the options were both mutually exclusive and relatively high-stakes, and there were enough to fragment people:
- do nothing (status quo from Pectra)
- some "minimal" EOF (didn't really satisfy everyone who thought that a major point of EOF was remove gas introspection)
- "status quo" EOF (tooling/some conceptual issues about, are people 100% sure either the delay in adoption was ok, or it's otherwise fine not to support gas introspection ever, either way)
- do nothing, plan/wait for something RISC-V based

among other outcomes. these were different enough to fragment people in a way that's a bit unusual in EIPs, where mostly it's yes/no with tweaks which don't fundamentally affect things and can be safely made later

author: pipermerriam
content: I'm not intending to prescribe a solution, but rather understand the situation and structures that produced the current situation.  I have my subjective opinions about what happened, but my parent comment is intended to try and hit an objective measure of the situation with as little subjectivity as possible.  It's possible that our current lack of structure is worth this cost if we are convinced that anti-capture is important enough and the mechanism is effective enough.

author: greystroke
